data.question:
You use the show ip route command on your router and see the information shown below:
Gateway of last resort is 192.168.2.12 to network 0.0.0.0
C 192.168.1.0/24 is directly connected, FastEthernet0/0
C 192.168.2.0/24 is directly connected, FastEthernet0/1
C 192.168.11.0/24 is directly connected, FastEthernet1/0
R 192.168.15.0/24 [120/1] via 192.168.1.15, 00:00:25, FastEthernet0/0
R 192.168.20.0/24 [120/2] via 192.168.1.15, 00:00:25, FastEthernet0/0
R 192.168.25.0/24 [120/1] via 192.168.11.15, 00:00:12, FastEthernet1/0
S* 0.0.0.0/0 [1/0] via 192.168.2.12

Which of these address/router interfaces pairs used to reach the destination network is not correct?
How does a router use frames to route data through a network?
data.correct_answer: The router checks the MAC address in the frame, replaces the MAC address of the source with its own MAC address, and sends it to the proper host.
data.incorrect_answers__001: The router checks the MAC address in the frame, uses ARP to compare it to the routing table, then replaces the destination MAC address with its own before sending it to the proper host.
data.incorrect_answers__002: The router uses ARP to find the logical address of the receiving host, replaces the MAC address with the logical address, and sends the frame to the proper host.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The router checks the logical address in the frame, replaces the logical address of the sender with the receiver's MAC address, and sends it to the proper host.
data.explanation: A router receives frames with both the source and destination devices' MAC addresses in the header. The router checks the header to determine whether the device is on its own network. It may use ARP to request the address if it does not appear in the routing table. The router then replaces the source address in the frame with the MAC address of the port connected to the correct network and forwards the frame through the correct port.
incorrect_answers: The router checks the MAC address in the frame, uses ARP to compare it to the routing table, then replaces the destination MAC address with its own before sending it to the proper host.
The router uses ARP to find the logical address of the receiving host, replaces the MAC address with the logical address, and sends the frame to the proper host.
The router checks the logical address in the frame, replaces the logical address of the sender with the receiver's MAC address, and sends it to the proper host.

data.question:
You use the show ip route command on a Cisco router and see the following information:
Codes: C - connected, S - static, R - RIP, M - mobile, B - BGP
D - EIGRP, EX - EIGRP external, O - OSPF, IA - OSPF inter area
N1 - OSPF NSSA external type 1, N2 - OSPF NSSA external type 2
E1 - OSPF external type 1, E2 - OSPF external type 2
I - IS-IS, su - IS-IS summary, L1 - IS-IS level-1, L2 - IS-IS level-2
ia - IS-IS inter area, * - candidate default, U - per-user static route
o - ODR, P - periodic downloaded static route
Gateway of last resort is not set
R 10.0.0.0/8 [120/3] via 192.168.4.14, 00:00:02, Serial0/1/0
C 192.168.1.0/24 is directly connected, FastEthernet0/0
192.168.4.0/30 is subnetted, 1 subnets
C 192.168.4.12 is directly connected, Serial0/1/0
D 172.16.0.0/16 [90/2172416] via 192.168.4.14, 00:00:49, Serial0/1/0
O 172.17.0.0/16 [110/68] via 192.168.4.14, 00:00:25, Serial0/1/0

Which of the following are true?
data.correct_answer: For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost  and The router has learned about routes through three routing protocols
data.incorrect_answers__001: The cost to network 172.16.0.0 is less than the cost to network 10.0.0.0 and For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost
data.incorrect_answers__002: The cost to network 172.16.0.0 is less than the cost to network 10.0.0.0 and For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost and The route to 172.16.0.0 is preferred over the route to 10.0.0.0 or 172.16.0.0
data.incorrect_answers__003: The cost to network 172.17.0.0 is less than the cost to network 172.16.0.0 and The router has learned about routes through three routing protocols
data.explanation:
As indicated by the first letter before each route entry, this router has learned about routes through three routing protocols: RIP (R), OSPF (O), and EIGRP (D). A route marked with C indicates a directly-connected route. For each route, the second number in brackets is the route cost.
Because each routing protocol uses a different metric to calculate the route cost, the route cost has meaning only within the same routing protocol. In other words, you cannot compare the route cost of a RIP route with the route cost of an OSPF route.
The first number in brackets is the administrative distance. The router uses these values to select the source of information to use when multiple routes to a destination exist. A smaller number indicates a more trusted route. The administrative distance is only used in the selection of routes if the router has learned of two routes to the same network through different routing protocols. When that happens, the protocol or route with the lower administrative distance is used. Typically this means that alternate routes will not appear in the routing table.
When routing packets, the network address is used to identify the route to use. If two routes exist to the same destination, the one with the lowest cost value is used. Neither the administrative distance nor the cost can be used to send a packet to an alternate destination.
incorrect_answers: The cost to network 172.16.0.0 is less than the cost to network 10.0.0.0 and For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost

The cost to network 172.16.0.0 is less than the cost to network 10.0.0.0 and For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost For the route to 172.17.0.0, the number 68 indicates the route cost and The route to 172.16.0.0 is preferred over the route to 10.0.0.0 or 172.16.0.0
The cost to network 172.17.0.0 is less than the cost to network 172.16.0.0 and The router has learned about routes through three routing protocols

data.question:
You are troubleshooting a basic serial connection on your router. The show interface serial 0/1/0 command shows the following information:
Serial0/1/0 is up, line protocol is down
Hardware is GT96K Serial
Internet address is 192.168.2.1/24
MTU 1500 bytes, BW 1544 Kbit, DLY 20000 usec,
reliability 255/255, txload 1/255, rxload 1/255
Encapsulation HDLC, loopback not set
Keepalive set (10 sec)... (additional output omitted)

What should be your first step in troubleshooting the problem?
data.correct_answer: Verify that the encapsulation is correctly configured.
data.explanation: To configure a static route for a Cisco router, use the ip route command, then specify the destination network, subnet mask, and default gateway IP address or outgoing interface.
incorrect_answers: Verify that the remote router has an IP address set.
See if you can establish a Telnet session with the remote router.
Check the cable connector on the router.

data.question:
You are troubleshooting a basic serial connection on your router. The show interface serial 0/1/0 command shows the following information:
Serial0/1/0 is down, line protocol is down
Hardware is GT96K Serial
Internet address is 192.168.2.1/24
MTU 1500 bytes, BW 1544 Kbit, DLY 20000 usec,
reliability 255/255, txload 1/255, rxload 1/255
Encapsulation HDLC, loopback not set
Keepalive set (10 sec)... (additional output omitted)

What should be your first step in troubleshooting the problem?
data.correct_answer: Check the cable connector on the router.
data.explanation:
The ip route command requires the following parameters:
  • Subnet address of the remote network. In this example, the subnet address is 192.168.111.128. The fa0/0 interface on RouterA has been assigned the IP address of 192.168.111.193, which is on the .128 subnet.
  • Subnet mask of the remote networks. A 25-bit mask is 255.255.255.128 decimal.
  • The interface on the local router used to reach the remote network (fa0/0) or the IP address of the next hop router, in this case the IP address on SubnetB for RouterA (172.18.12.197).
incorrect_answers: See if you can ping the remote router.
Verify that the encapsulation is correctly configured.
See if you can establish a Telnet session with the remote router.

data.question:
IP traffic destined for a device configured with the address 10.10.34.4/24 is congesting the network. The network administrator issues a traceroute command from the local router and receives the output shown below.
Router#traceroute 10.10.34.4

Type escape sequence to abort.
Tracing the route to 10.10.34.4

1 192.168.12.2 20 msec 20 msec 20 msec
2 192.168.12.1 8 msec 12 msec 8 msec
3 192.168.12.2 8 msec 8 msec 12 msec
4 192.168.12.1 12 msec 8 msec 8 msec
5 192.168.12.2 8 msec 8 msec 12 msec
6 192.168.12.1 8 msec 12 msec 8 msec
! -- remaining output omitted --
What is the cause of the problem?
data.correct_answer: A loop exists between two of the routers.
data.incorrect_answers__001: The routing table is missing a static route to 10.10.34.4.
data.incorrect_answers__002: The interface on the local router is administratively down.
data.incorrect_answers__003: The device with the address 10.10.34.4 is in the wrong subnet.
data.explanation:
A loop exists between two of the routers. The traffic is bouncing between the interface address 192.168.12.1 and the interface address 192.168.12.2
If the device with the address 10.10.34.4 was is in the wrong subnet, the traceroute would read 'Host unreachable'. If the interface on the local router was administratively down, the traceroute would have no output. A missing route to 10.10.34.4 would generate the message 'Network unreachable'.
incorrect_answers: The routing table is missing a static route to 10.10.34.4.
The interface on the local router is administratively down.
The device with the address 10.10.34.4 is in the wrong subnet.

data.question: Which of these routing methods on the left is matched correctly with its associated characteristics on the right?
data.correct_answer: Provides complete control over routes:  Static routing
data.incorrect_answers__001: Keeps routing tables on each router up to date: static routing
data.incorrect_answers__002: Most appropriate on networks that don't change frequently: dynamic routing
data.incorrect_answers__003: Propagates changes in the network topology: static routing
data.explanation:
Static routing is an addressing method in which IP routing information must be built and updated manually. Use static routing:
  • When administrators need complete control over the routes that are used by a router
  • On networks with a very small number of hosts
  • On networks that do not change often or that will not grow
  • In environments with low-capacity routers that wouldn't optimally support a dynamic routing system
  • To back up a dynamic route
  • On networks with slow bandwidth links (such as dial-up)
  • In scenarios in which a route needs to appear to the router as a directly connected network
Dynamic routing is an addressing method that senses changes in the network topology and responds accordingly without administrator involvement. Dynamic routers:
  • Propagate changes and shifts in the network topology to each router in the network, causing the routing tables on each router to always be up to date
  • Are responsible for all networks to which they are connected
  • Employ additional processes or services to exchange routing information between routers
incorrect_answers: Keeps routing tables on each router up to date: static routing
Most appropriate on networks that don't change frequently: dynamic routing
Propagates changes in the network topology: static routing

data.question: Which of the default administrative distance with the route type is correct?
data.explanation:
The administrative distance is a number assigned to a source of routing information (such as a static route or a specific routing protocol). The router uses these values to select the source of information to use when multiple routes to a destination exist. A smaller number indicates a more trusted route.
  • Static routes have an administrative distance of 1.
  • EIGRP internal routes have an administrative distance of 90.
  • OSPF has an administrative distance of 110.
  • RIP has an administrative distance of 120.
  • EIGRP external routes have an administrative distance of 170.

data.question: You are the administrator of the network shown in the Exhibit. You want to configure the stub network located in Tampa to forward packets to Chicago, but you do not want the overhead associated with a routing protocol. Which of the following will accomplish your goal?
data.explanation:
The stub router, Tampa, should be configured with the default route address 0.0.0.0, while the Chicago router is statically configured with all possible networks attached to the stub router. Use the following commands:
Tampa(config)#ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 182.1.48.3
Chicago(config)#ip route 182.1.48.0 255.255.240.0 182.1.48.4
Chicago(config)#ip route 192.168.112.128 255.255.255.248
182.1.48.4

data.question:
You need to configure a static route on your Cisco router. The destination network is 192.65.178.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0. The default gateway is 192.65.179.1, and the IP address of the destination host for the message is 192.65.178.15.
Which of the following commands configures this route?
data.explanation: To configure a static route for a Cisco router, use the ip route command, then specify the destination network, subnet mask, and default gateway IP address or outgoing interface.

data.question:
You have a small network with IP addresses assigned to router interfaces as shown in the Exhibit. You need to configure a static route on RouterB for SubnetA.
Which command would you use?
data.explanation:
The ip route command requires the following parameters:
  • Subnet address of the remote network. In this example, the subnet address is 192.168.111.128. The fa0/0 interface on RouterA has been assigned the IP address of 192.168.111.193, which is on the .128 subnet.
  • Subnet mask of the remote networks. A 25-bit mask is 255.255.255.128 decimal.
  • The interface on the local router used to reach the remote network (fa0/0) or the IP address of the next hop router, in this case the IP address on SubnetB for RouterA (172.18.12.197).

data.question:
You have a network with two routers as shown in the Exhibit. RouterA and RouterB are configured to use RIP version 2 with auto-summarization enabled.
Which summarized network entry will RouterA have in its routing table for the subnets connected to RouterB?
data.explanation: Subnets on RouterB will be summarized as 192.168.12.0/24. Auto-summarization with RIP v2 or EIGRP summarizes routes along classful network boundaries (i.e. the default subnet mask is used).

data.question:
You have a network with two routers as shown in the Exhibit. You would like to configure a single static route on RouterA that summarizes the routes accessible through RouterB.
Which static route would you configure?
data.explanation:
The summarized route will use the subnet address of 172.17.1.64 with a mask of 255.255.255.192. The 26-bit mask includes addresses in the range of 172.17.1.64 to 172.17.1.127.
The summarized route does not include the subnet of the directly-connected network (172.17.1.48). In addition, you cannot use a mask of 255.255.255.192 with this subnet because .48 is not a valid subnet address (valid subnets would be 0, 64, 128, or 192). Using a mask of 255.255.255.128 is also not allowed for subnet 172.17.1.64 (valid subnet addresses with this mask would be 0 and 128).

data.question:
You have a network with three routers as shown in the Exhibit.
All routers are configured to share information for all known routes using the same routing protocol. Automatic summarization is enabled.
Router B shares its known networks with router C. Which of the following routes will be in router C's routing table?
data.explanation:
Router C will have a single entry to network 172.16.0.0/16. Because the link between router B and router C crosses a classful subnet boundary, then the three subnetted networks connected to router B will be summarized as a single network. Auto-summarization summarizes routes based on classful network boundaries. Because an address of 172.16.x.x is a class B network, a 16-bit mask is used when summarizing those routes.
If you had turned the routing protocol off, you could summarize the three networks on router B as a single network of 172.16.2.0/26. If the link between router B and router C was on the 172.16.0.0/16 classful network, then router B would not summarize the routes when reporting them to router C.
